Abstract

Federated Learning (FL) is a distributed learning paradigm that enables multiple clients to collaborate on building a machine learning model without sharing their private data. Although FL is considered privacy-preserved by design, recent data reconstruction attacks demonstrate that an attacker can recover clientsâ€™ training data based on the parameters shared in FL. However, most existing methods fail to attack the most widely used horizontal Federated Averaging (FedAvg) scenario, where clients share model parameters after multiple local training steps. To tackle this issue, we propose an interpolation-based approximation method, which makes attacking FedAvg scenarios feasible by generating the intermediate model updates of the clientsâ€™ local training processes. Then, we design a layer-wise weighted loss function to improve the data quality of reconstruction. We assign different weights to model updates in different layers concerning the neural network structure, with the weights tuned by Bayesian optimization. Finally, experimental results validate the superiority of our proposed approximate and weighted attack (AWA) method over the other state-of-the-art methods, as demonstrated by the substantial improvement in different evaluation metrics for image data reconstructions.

1 Introduction

With the increasing volume of data generated by distributed personal electronic devices and organizations, traditional centralized approaches for training machine learning models face challenges in terms of data collection, privacy concerns, and scalability. To address them, Federated Learning (FL) li2020federated ; mcmahan2023communicationefficient has emerged as a promising paradigm and has gained significant attention in recent years.

One prominent feature of FL is its ability to facilitate model training on distributed data sources owned by individual clients while keeping the data localized and exchanging only model updates. For example, in the most commonly used Federated Averaging (FedAvg) mcmahan2023communicationefficient algorithm, each client trains its local model with its private data and shares the updated model parameters to a server, where the model parameters are aggregated and used to update the global model. In other words, FL enables multiple participants to build a common and robust machine learning model without sharing data, thus addressing critical issues such as data privacy, data security, and data access rights. FL has gained significant attention in recent years to handle the growing amount of data and the increasing concerns about privacy in a number of applications, such as healthcare brisimi2018federated ; xu2021federated , and learning a controller model across several autonomous vehicles without sharing their history trajectories zeng2022federated .

Although it was widely believed that model updates in FL are safe to share, recent studies geng2023improved ; xu2022agic ; yin2021see ; zhu2019deep have shown that clientsâ€™ sensitive training data can be compromised through data reconstruction attacks zhu2019deep . In these attacks, the adversary randomly initializes dummy samples and labels, and executes forward and backward propagation to obtain dummy model updates. Through an iterative process of minimizing the discrepancy between the dummy model updates and the shared ones, the dummy samples and labels are updated simultaneously. In the literature, some work has already been done for improving the reconstruction performance, we refer to the label inference techniques in yin2021see ; zhao2020idlg , the new distance functions and optimizers in geiping2020inverting ; wang2020sapag , and the regularization methods in geiping2020inverting ; jeon2021gradient ; wei2020framework .

By inferring labels in advance, the joint optimization of both samples and labels can be avoided, thus reducing the complexity of the optimization problem. It was first discovered in zhao2020idlg that the label information of a single sample can be analytically extracted based on the model updates of the last fully connected layer. Later, yin2021see extended the single sample label extraction to batch samples, under the limiting assumption of non-repeating labels in the batch. The above limitation is further addressed by the batch label inference approach proposed in geng2023improved .

To measure the discrepancy between the dummy and shared gradients, the Euclidean distance is commonly used in the loss function for the attack, see yin2021see ; zhao2020idlg ; zhu2019deep . Moreover, the angle-based cosine similarity was suggested in geiping2020inverting ; xu2022agic since the high-dimensional direction of the gradients carries more information than the magnitude. In wang2020sapag , a Gaussian kernel of gradients differences was proposed to measure the discrepancy, allowing the scaling factor in the kernel to be adapted to the distribution of gradients in each attack.

As for the optimizers employed in the attacks, the L-BFGS liu1989limited and the Adam kingma2017adam are the most commonly used ones, see e.g., geiping2020inverting ; jeon2021gradient ; wang2020sapag ; wei2020framework ; yin2021see ; zhao2020idlg ; zhu2019deep . In particular, the reconstruction performance of the above two optimizers was compared in geiping2020inverting ; wang2020sapag ; wei2020framework . It has been shown in wei2020framework that the L-BFGS requires fewer attack iterations to achieve high reconstruction quality compared to the Adam when attacking the LFW dataset huang2008labeled . On the other hand, in geiping2020inverting , the L-BFGS performs worse than the Adam for the CIFAR-10 dataset krizhevsky2009learning . Although there is no definitive analysis guiding the selection of cost functions and optimizers, it is evident that appropriate choices can enhance the effectiveness of attacks in specific scenarios.

Another important way to improve the reconstruction performance is to add auxiliary regularization terms to the loss function for the attack based on some prior knowledge of the data. In wei2020framework , a label regularizer was proposed to match the dummy samples and labels when both of them are optimized simultaneously. Moreover, some image prior information can be employed for image reconstruction attacks, such as the total variation regularization geiping2020inverting to reduce the noise in images, and the group registration regularization yin2021see to center the position of the main object in images. In yin2021see , a prior term is proposed by using the values of the mean and variance of a batch of samples in batch normalization layers. A generative model pre-trained on the raw data distribution was used in jeon2021gradient to improve the reconstruction. However, in most distributed learning systems, batch normalization information and raw data distribution are not necessarily shared, which makes these methods less practical.

Despite remarkable progress, limited attention has been paid to attacking the FedAvg with multiple-step model updates, where clients share accumulated local model parameters after training for multiple epochs, each executed over multiple mini-batches. In this regard, an approximate and weighted method, named AGIC, is proposed in xu2022agic . The AGIC method employs a weighted cosine similarity loss function by assigning linearly increasing weights to different convolutional and fully connected layers. This method assumes that a combined batch consisting of all the mini-batches used in the clientâ€™s local training process can approximate the received model update in a single local update step. However, such an approximation method works only for scenarios with small local learning rates. Moreover, the weights are chosen empirically rather than systematically.

To address the above issues, we propose a novel approximate and weighted data reconstruction attack method against FL systems utilizing FedAvg algorithms. First, we present an interpolation-based approximation method that generates intermediate model updates of clientsâ€™ local training processes. As a result, attacking against the FedAvg with multiple-step model updates becomes feasible. Then, we propose a layer-wise weighted loss function to enhance the reconstruction quality. Different weights are assigned to model updates in each layer based on the neural network structure. The selection of the weights is optimized using the Bayesian optimization method.

Overall, our main contributions are as follows:

  1. 1.

    To attack the FedAvg with multiple-step model updates, we propose an interpolation-based approximation method. The model update corresponding to each epoch is approximated by interpolating the received combined model updates. The proposed approximation method makes attacks against FedAvg scenarios feasible and effective, as demonstrated by numerical experiments.

  2. 2.

    To further improve the attack performance after approximation, we employ a layer-wise weighted loss function for the attack. Different weights are assigned to different layers, and these weights are determined by the Bayesian optimization frazier2018tutorial . Additionally, we enhance the weights of layers with relatively larger errors, improving the attackâ€™s adaptability and performance.

  3. 3.

    Our method demonstrates environment generality by being compatible with various neural network architectures, such as Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) and Residual Neural Networks (ResNets). Furthermore, it is capable of reconstructing training data based on the model updates leaked at different stages of the training process.

The rest of the paper is organized as follows. In SectionÂ 2, we provide a comprehensive background on FL and data reconstruction attacks. In Section 3, various attack scenarios are analyzed to identify the most challenging one. SectionÂ 4 presents our proposed method, including the approximation method and the layer-wise weighted loss function. The experimental setup and simulation results are presented in SectionÂ 5. Finally, we conclude the paper in SectionÂ 6.

2 Preliminaries

In this section, we first provide a detailed description of the mathematical formulation and training process of FL. Then, we introduce the formulation and setup of data reconstruction attacks.

2.2 FedAvg Algorithm

For solving (1), FL algorithms normally combine local model update processes performed by each client with model aggregation steps performed by a central server. To fix ideas, we focus on the FedAvg mcmahan2023communicationefficient , which is the most commonly used algorithm in FL. The FedAvg presented in AlgorithmÂ 1 involves a series of global rounds, in which the server first dispatches the latest global model parameters to a group of selected clients. Then, the selected clients compute model updates to the current global model with their private data and send the updated model parameters back to the server. Finally, the server aggregates the received model parameters to update the global model parameters, which serves as the initializer for the next round.

Next, we elaborate on the implementation of AlgorithmÂ 1. 2.3 Data Reconstruction Attack

Despite the fact that the clients only share the updated model parameters with the server, their private training data are still vulnerable to data reconstruction attacks geiping2020inverting ; yin2021see ; zhu2019deep . In this subsection, we introduce the formulation and the general procedure of a data reconstruction attack.

As shown in (4), during the local training process at round tğ‘¡t, client kğ‘˜kâ€™s model parameters update Î”â€‹Î¸t(k)Î”superscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘¡ğ‘˜\Delta\theta_{t}^{(k)} consists of the averaged gradients computed on EÃ—B(k)ğ¸superscriptğµğ‘˜E\times B^{(k)} mini-batches. Let Gt(k)superscriptsubscriptğºğ‘¡ğ‘˜G_{t}^{(k)} be a mapping from the training data {(X(k),Y(k))}superscriptğ‘‹ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘Œğ‘˜\{(X^{(k)},Y^{(k)})\} defined in (2) to the model parameters update Î”â€‹Î¸t(k)Î”superscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘¡ğ‘˜\Delta\theta_{t}^{(k)}, then we can rewrite (4) in a compact manner as

Î”â€‹Î¸t(k)=Gt(k)â€‹(X(k),Y(k)).Î”superscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘¡ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğºğ‘¡ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘‹ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘Œğ‘˜\Delta\theta_{t}^{(k)}=G_{t}^{(k)}\left(X^{(k)},Y^{(k)}\right). (7)

For an attacker with access to Î”â€‹Î¸t(k)Î”superscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘¡ğ‘˜\Delta\theta_{t}^{(k)}, reconstructing {(X(k),Y(k))}superscriptğ‘‹ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘Œğ‘˜\{(X^{(k)},Y^{(k)})\} is essentially an inverse problem. In particular, if [Gt(k)]âˆ’1superscriptdelimited-[]superscriptsubscriptğºğ‘¡ğ‘˜1[G_{t}^{(k)}]^{-1} exists and is known analytically, the attacker can recover {(X(k),Y(k))}superscriptğ‘‹ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘Œğ‘˜\{(X^{(k)},Y^{(k)})\} directly as follows:

(X(k),Y(k))=[Gt(k)]âˆ’1â€‹(Î”â€‹Î¸t(k)).superscriptğ‘‹ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘Œğ‘˜superscriptdelimited-[]superscriptsubscriptğºğ‘¡ğ‘˜1Î”superscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘¡ğ‘˜\left(X^{(k)},Y^{(k)}\right)=[G_{t}^{(k)}]^{-1}\left(\Delta\theta_{t}^{(k)}\right). (8)

Notice that the attacker can independently attack any client kâˆˆğ’¦ğ‘˜ğ’¦k\in\mathcal{K} that participated in the training at round tğ‘¡t.

However, since neural networks are highly nonlinear and the model updates are aggregated over multiple mini-batches, it is generally difficult to identify [Gt(k)]âˆ’1superscriptdelimited-[]superscriptsubscriptğºğ‘¡ğ‘˜1[G_{t}^{(k)}]^{-1}. To address this issue, we introduce a numerical approach for solving (7). In the sequel we omit the superscript kğ‘˜k to simplify the notation.

Assuming an attacker can get access to the clientâ€™s training process and hence knows Gtsubscriptğºğ‘¡G_{t}, then problem (7) can be solved by the numerical approach elaborated below. First, to launch the attack, the attacker randomly initializes a dummy dataset (X^,Y^)^ğ‘‹^ğ‘Œ(\hat{X},\hat{Y}) with the same dimension as that of the clientâ€™s original dataset (X,Y)ğ‘‹ğ‘Œ(X,Y). The attacker uses Gtsubscriptğºğ‘¡G_{t} to calculate the dummy model update Î”â€‹Î¸^tÎ”subscript^ğœƒğ‘¡\Delta\hat{\theta}_{t} given by

Î”â€‹Î¸^t=Gtâ€‹(X^,Y^).Î”subscript^ğœƒğ‘¡subscriptğºğ‘¡^ğ‘‹^ğ‘Œ\Delta\hat{\theta}_{t}=G_{t}(\hat{X},\hat{Y}). (9)

Proceeding as in zhu2019deep , the attacker can reconstruct the clientâ€™s dataset by matching the dummy model update Î”â€‹Î¸^tÎ”subscript^ğœƒğ‘¡\Delta\hat{\theta}_{t} with the ground-truth model update Î”â€‹Î¸tÎ”subscriptğœƒğ‘¡\Delta\theta_{t}, minimizing a model update matching loss function â„“msubscriptâ„“ğ‘š\ell_{m} given by

â„“mâ€‹(X^,Y^)=â€–Î”â€‹Î¸^tâˆ’Î”â€‹Î¸tâ€–2=â€–Gtâ€‹(X^,Y^)âˆ’Gtâ€‹(X,Y)â€–2.subscriptâ„“ğ‘š^ğ‘‹^ğ‘ŒsuperscriptnormÎ”subscript^ğœƒğ‘¡Î”subscriptğœƒğ‘¡2superscriptnormsubscriptğºğ‘¡^ğ‘‹^ğ‘Œsubscriptğºğ‘¡ğ‘‹ğ‘Œ2\ell_{m}(\hat{X},\hat{Y})=\|\Delta\hat{\theta}_{t}-\Delta\theta_{t}\|^{2}=\left\|G_{t}(\hat{X},\hat{Y})-G_{t}(X,Y)\right\|^{2}. (10)

Therefore, the data reconstruction attack can be conducted by solving the following optimization problem:

(X^âˆ—,Y^âˆ—)=argâ¡minX^,Y^â¡â„“mâ€‹(X^,Y^).superscript^ğ‘‹superscript^ğ‘Œsubscript^ğ‘‹^ğ‘Œsubscriptâ„“ğ‘š^ğ‘‹^ğ‘Œ(\hat{X}^{*},\hat{Y}^{*})=\arg\min_{\hat{X},\hat{Y}}\ell_{m}(\hat{X},\hat{Y}). (11)

This can be done using the gradient descent method with the learning rate Î·^^ğœ‚\hat{\eta}:

X^â†X^âˆ’Î·^â€‹âˆ‡X^â„“mâ€‹(X^,Y^),Y^â†Y^âˆ’Î·^â€‹âˆ‡Y^â„“mâ€‹(X^,Y^).formulae-sequenceâ†^ğ‘‹^ğ‘‹^ğœ‚subscriptâˆ‡^ğ‘‹subscriptâ„“ğ‘š^ğ‘‹^ğ‘Œâ†^ğ‘Œ^ğ‘Œ^ğœ‚subscriptâˆ‡^ğ‘Œsubscriptâ„“ğ‘š^ğ‘‹^ğ‘Œ\hat{X}\leftarrow\hat{X}-\hat{\eta}\nabla_{\hat{X}}\ell_{m}(\hat{X},\hat{Y}),\quad\hat{Y}\leftarrow\hat{Y}-\hat{\eta}\nabla_{\hat{Y}}\ell_{m}(\hat{X},\hat{Y}).
Remark 2.1.

In FL, the central server holds a substantial amount of information about the training process. Data reconstruction attacks can typically be developed by a honest-but-curious server geiping2020inverting , acting as attacker, who has access to the following information, and in particular Gtsubscriptğºğ‘¡G_{t} in (9).

  1. 1.

    Model architecture of hhh: Normally the server decides the architecture of the neural network that is shared among all the clients.

  2. 2.

    Initial model parameters Î¸tsubscriptÎ¸t\theta_{t}: For each client, its initial local model parameter Î¸tsubscriptğœƒğ‘¡\theta_{t} is dispatched from the server.

  3. 3.

    Model parameters update Î”â€‹Î¸tÎ”subscriptÎ¸t\Delta\theta_{t}: Each client sends the updated model parameters Î¸t+1subscriptğœƒğ‘¡1\theta_{t+1} obtained in (5) back to the server. Thus, Î”â€‹Î¸t=Î¸t+1âˆ’Î¸tÎ”subscriptğœƒğ‘¡subscriptğœƒğ‘¡1subscriptğœƒğ‘¡\Delta\theta_{t}=\theta_{t+1}-\theta_{t} can be obtained by the server easily.

  4. 4.

    Loss function â„“â„“\ell: Similar to hâ„h, it is common that the server decides the form of the loss function that is shared among all the clients. The choice made is kept unchanged during the training process.

  5. 5.

    Dataset size NNN: This information is shared with the server for weighted aggregation as shown in (6).

  6. 6.

    Clientâ€™s local training hyperparameters: As shown in (4) and (7), the knowledge of Gtsubscriptğºğ‘¡G_{t} depends on the hyperparameters listed below. In general cases, the server can assign these hyperparameters to each client.

    1. (a)

      Number of epochs Eğ¸E

    2. (b)

      Number of mini-batches BğµB

    3. (c)

      Learning rate Î·ğœ‚\eta

3 Analysis of Attack Scenarios: Different Eğ¸E and BğµB

As shown in (9), a data reconstruction attack requires the knowledge of Gtsubscriptğºğ‘¡G_{t} to calculate the dummy model update Î”â€‹Î¸^tÎ”subscript^ğœƒğ‘¡\Delta\hat{\theta}_{t}. In this section, we discuss the difficulty of knowing Gtsubscriptğºğ‘¡G_{t} for four FedAvg scenarios in terms of different values of Eğ¸E and BğµB and, in particular, when E>1ğ¸1E>1 and B>1ğµ1B>1.

Scenario 1: E=1,B=1formulae-sequenceğ¸1ğµ1E=1,B=1.

As we shall see, the attacker can get access to Gtsubscriptğºğ‘¡G_{t} and replicate the clientâ€™s training process. Indeed, since E=1ğ¸1E=1 and B=1ğµ1B=1, the client uses the whole dataset for one epoch as follows:

Gtâ€‹(X,Y)=âˆ’Î·â€‹âˆ‡Î¸tâ„“â€‹(X,Y)=âˆ’Î·â€‹1Nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1Nâˆ‡Î¸tâ„“â€‹(xi,yi).subscriptğºğ‘¡ğ‘‹ğ‘Œğœ‚subscriptâˆ‡subscriptğœƒğ‘¡â„“ğ‘‹ğ‘Œğœ‚1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘subscriptâˆ‡subscriptğœƒğ‘¡â„“subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–G_{t}(X,Y)=-\eta\nabla_{\theta_{t}}\ell\left(X,Y\right)=-\eta\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\nabla_{\theta_{t}}\ell\left(x_{i},y_{i}\right). (12)

Thus, the attacker can replicate the clientâ€™s training process by replacing (X,Y)ğ‘‹ğ‘Œ(X,Y) with the dummy dataset (X^,Y^)={(x^i,y^i)}i=1N^ğ‘‹^ğ‘Œsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript^ğ‘¥ğ‘–subscript^ğ‘¦ğ‘–ğ‘–1ğ‘(\hat{X},\hat{Y})=\{(\hat{x}_{i},\hat{y}_{i})\}_{i=1}^{N} in the following way:

Gtâ€‹(X^,Y^)=âˆ’Î·â€‹âˆ‡Î¸tâ„“â€‹(X^,Y^)=âˆ’Î·â€‹1Nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1Nâˆ‡Î¸tâ„“â€‹(x^i,y^i).subscriptğºğ‘¡^ğ‘‹^ğ‘Œğœ‚subscriptâˆ‡subscriptğœƒğ‘¡â„“^ğ‘‹^ğ‘Œğœ‚1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘subscriptâˆ‡subscriptğœƒğ‘¡â„“subscript^ğ‘¥ğ‘–subscript^ğ‘¦ğ‘–G_{t}(\hat{X},\hat{Y})=-\eta\nabla_{\theta_{t}}\ell\left(\hat{X},\hat{Y}\right)=-\eta\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\nabla_{\theta_{t}}\ell\left(\hat{x}_{i},\hat{y}_{i}\right). (13)
Scenario 2: E>1,B=1formulae-sequenceğ¸1ğµ1E>1,B=1.

The attacker can also obtain the knowledge of Gtsubscriptğºğ‘¡G_{t} in this scenario. To be concrete, the client uses the batch gradient descent for Eğ¸E epochs:

Gtâ€‹(X,Y)=âˆ’Î·â€‹âˆ‘e=1Eâˆ‡Î¸t,eâ„“â€‹(X,Y).subscriptğºğ‘¡ğ‘‹ğ‘Œğœ‚superscriptsubscriptğ‘’1ğ¸subscriptâˆ‡subscriptğœƒğ‘¡ğ‘’â„“ğ‘‹ğ‘ŒG_{t}(X,Y)=-\eta\sum_{e=1}^{E}\nabla_{\theta_{t,e}}\ell\left(X,Y\right). (14)

In each epoch, since B=1ğµ1B=1, the gradients are computed on the Nğ‘N samples, as in Scenario 1. In this case, the attacker can replicate the clientâ€™s training process by replacing (X,Y)ğ‘‹ğ‘Œ(X,Y) with the dummy dataset (X^,Y^)^ğ‘‹^ğ‘Œ(\hat{X},\hat{Y}), and train the model for Eğ¸E epochs as follows:

Gtâ€‹(X^,Y^)=âˆ’Î·â€‹âˆ‘e=1Eâˆ‡Î¸t,eâ„“â€‹(X^,Y^).subscriptğºğ‘¡^ğ‘‹^ğ‘Œğœ‚superscriptsubscriptğ‘’1ğ¸subscriptâˆ‡subscriptğœƒğ‘¡ğ‘’â„“^ğ‘‹^ğ‘ŒG_{t}(\hat{X},\hat{Y})=-\eta\sum_{e=1}^{E}\nabla_{\theta_{t,e}}\ell\left(\hat{X},\hat{Y}\right). (15)
Scenario 3: E=1,B>1formulae-sequenceğ¸1ğµ1E=1,B>1.

In this scenario, since B>1ğµ1B>1, the client uses the mini-batch gradient descent for one epoch in the following way:

Gtâ€‹(X,Y)=âˆ’Î·â€‹âˆ‘b=1Bâˆ‡Î¸t,bâ„“â€‹(Xt,b,Yt,b)subscriptğºğ‘¡ğ‘‹ğ‘Œğœ‚superscriptsubscriptğ‘1ğµsubscriptâˆ‡subscriptğœƒğ‘¡ğ‘â„“subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘¡ğ‘subscriptğ‘Œğ‘¡ğ‘G_{t}(X,Y)=-\eta\sum_{b=1}^{B}\nabla_{\theta_{t,b}}\ell\left(X_{t,b},Y_{t,b}\right) (16)

with the gradients computed on BğµB mini-batches. At each epoch of the mini-batch gradient descent method, the client randomly shuffled the dataset and separates it into BğµB mini-batches. In this scenario, since E=1ğ¸1E=1, the dataset is only shuffled once.

The attacker can first separate its dummy dataset (X^,Y^)^ğ‘‹^ğ‘Œ(\hat{X},\hat{Y}) into BğµB mini-batches {(X^t,b,Y^t,b)}b=1Bsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript^ğ‘‹ğ‘¡ğ‘subscript^ğ‘Œğ‘¡ğ‘ğ‘1ğµ\{(\hat{X}_{t,b},\hat{Y}_{t,b})\}_{b=1}^{B}. Then, by replacing (Xt,b,Yt,b)subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘¡ğ‘subscriptğ‘Œğ‘¡ğ‘(X_{t,b},Y_{t,b}) in (16) with (X^t,b,Y^t,b)subscript^ğ‘‹ğ‘¡ğ‘subscript^ğ‘Œğ‘¡ğ‘(\hat{X}_{t,b},\hat{Y}_{t,b}), it can replicate the clientâ€™s training process as below:

Gtâ€‹(X^,Y^)=âˆ’Î·â€‹âˆ‘b=1Bâˆ‡Î¸t,bâ„“â€‹(X^t,b,Y^t,b).subscriptğºğ‘¡^ğ‘‹^ğ‘Œğœ‚superscriptsubscriptğ‘1ğµsubscriptâˆ‡subscriptğœƒğ‘¡ğ‘â„“subscript^ğ‘‹ğ‘¡ğ‘subscript^ğ‘Œğ‘¡ğ‘G_{t}(\hat{X},\hat{Y})=-\eta\sum_{b=1}^{B}\nabla_{\theta_{t,b}}\ell\left(\hat{X}_{t,b},\hat{Y}_{t,b}\right). (17)

The only difference is that the reconstructed (X^,Y^)^ğ‘‹^ğ‘Œ(\hat{X},\hat{Y}) are in the same order as that of the shuffled clientâ€™s dataset. Hence, the attacker can still obtain Gtsubscriptğºğ‘¡G_{t} and replicate the local training process in this scenario.

Scenario 4: E>1,B>1formulae-sequenceğ¸1ğµ1E>1,B>1.

In this case, the attacker cannot gain the needed knowledge of Gtsubscriptğºğ‘¡G_{t} to calculate the dummy model update Î”â€‹Î¸^tÎ”subscript^ğœƒğ‘¡\Delta\hat{\theta}_{t} defined in (9).

Indeed, the client uses the mini-batch gradient descent for Eğ¸E epochs:

Gtâ€‹(X,Y)=âˆ’Î·â€‹âˆ‘e=1Eâˆ‘b=1Bâˆ‡Î¸t,e,bâ„“â€‹(Xt,e,b,Yt,e,b).subscriptğºğ‘¡ğ‘‹ğ‘Œğœ‚superscriptsubscriptğ‘’1ğ¸superscriptsubscriptğ‘1ğµsubscriptâˆ‡subscriptğœƒğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘â„“subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘subscriptğ‘Œğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘G_{t}(X,Y)=-\eta\sum_{e=1}^{E}\sum_{b=1}^{B}\nabla_{\theta_{t,e,b}}\ell\left(X_{t,e,b},Y_{t,e,b}\right). (18)

In each epoch, the client first shuffles its dataset and then separates it into BğµB mini-batches. As a result, the attacker cannot replicate the clientâ€™s mini-batch separation when E>1ğ¸1E>1 due to the randomness of the shuffling process.

Most existing attack methods in the literature are only applicable to Scenarios 1-3 and limited attention has been given to the more challenging Scenario 4. To address it, we propose an interpolation-based approximation method. By interpolating the received model updates, we can approximate the model update corresponding to each epoch, thereby reducing the problem from Scenario 4 to Scenario 3. The details of the proposed method are presented in Section 4.1.

4 Approximate and Weighted Data Reconstruction Method

In this section, we propose an approximate and weighted data reconstruction attack method for solving (7).

4.1 Approximation of the intermediate model update {Î”â€‹Î¸t,e}e=1EsuperscriptsubscriptÎ”subscriptğœƒğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘’1ğ¸\{\Delta\theta_{t,e}\}_{e=1}^{E} when E>1ğ¸1E>1 and B>1ğµ1B>1

As discussed in SectionÂ 3, the shuffling of the dataset in each epoch makes it difficult for the attacker to know Gtsubscriptğºğ‘¡G_{t}. However, if we know the intermediate model update Î”â€‹Î¸t,e,eâˆˆ{1,2,â€¦,E}Î”subscriptğœƒğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘’12â€¦ğ¸\Delta\theta_{t,e},e\in\{1,2,\ldots,E\} of each epoch, the problem can be reduced from Scenario 4 (E>1ğ¸1E>1 and B>1ğµ1B>1) to Scenario 3 (E=1ğ¸1E=1 and B>1ğµ1B>1) by attacking each epoch separately.

To this end, we interpolate between Î¸t+1subscriptğœƒğ‘¡1\theta_{t+1} and Î¸tsubscriptğœƒğ‘¡\theta_{t} to approximate the intermediate model parameters {Î¸t,e}e=1Esuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘’1ğ¸\{\theta_{t,e}\}_{e=1}^{E} corresponding to each epoch. Particularly, consider a client who trains its model for Eğ¸E epochs, the approximate intermediate model parameters {Î¸~t,e}e=1Esuperscriptsubscriptsubscript~ğœƒğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘’1ğ¸\{\tilde{\theta}_{t,e}\}_{e=1}^{E} can be obtained as

Î¸~t,e=Î¸t+1âˆ’Î¸tEâ€‹e+Î¸tforÂ â€‹e=1,2,â€¦,E.formulae-sequencesubscript~ğœƒğ‘¡ğ‘’subscriptğœƒğ‘¡1subscriptğœƒğ‘¡ğ¸ğ‘’subscriptğœƒğ‘¡forÂ ğ‘’12â€¦ğ¸\tilde{\theta}_{t,e}=\frac{\theta_{t+1}-\theta_{t}}{E}e+\theta_{t}\quad\textnormal{for }e=1,2,\ldots,E. (19)

Then, the approximate model updates {Î”â€‹Î¸~t,e}e=1EsuperscriptsubscriptÎ”subscript~ğœƒğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘’1ğ¸\{\Delta\tilde{\theta}_{t,e}\}_{e=1}^{E} corresponding to each epoch can be obtained as

Î”â€‹Î¸~t,e=Î¸~t,eâˆ’Î¸~t,eâˆ’1forÂ â€‹e=1,2,â€¦,E,formulae-sequenceÎ”subscript~ğœƒğ‘¡ğ‘’subscript~ğœƒğ‘¡ğ‘’subscript~ğœƒğ‘¡ğ‘’1forÂ ğ‘’12â€¦ğ¸\Delta\tilde{\theta}_{t,e}=\tilde{\theta}_{t,e}-\tilde{\theta}_{t,e-1}\quad\textnormal{for }e=1,2,\ldots,E, (20)

where Î¸~t,0=Î¸tsubscript~ğœƒğ‘¡0subscriptğœƒğ‘¡\tilde{\theta}_{t,0}=\theta_{t} is the initial model parameter at round tğ‘¡t.

After obtaining the approximate {Î”â€‹Î¸~t,e}e=1EsuperscriptsubscriptÎ”subscript~ğœƒğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘’1ğ¸\{\Delta\tilde{\theta}_{t,e}\}_{e=1}^{E}, one can use it as the target model update of the corresponding epoch eâˆˆ{1,2,â€¦,E}ğ‘’12â€¦ğ¸e\in\{1,2,\ldots,E\}. In other words, the problem is reduced from Scenario 4 (E>1ğ¸1E>1 and B>1ğµ1B>1) to Scenario 3 (E=1ğ¸1E=1 and B>1ğµ1B>1).

Let Gt,esubscriptğºğ‘¡ğ‘’G_{t,e} denote the clientâ€™s training process of epoch eğ‘’e at round tğ‘¡t. Then, the dummy model update Î”â€‹Î¸^t,eÎ”subscript^ğœƒğ‘¡ğ‘’\Delta\hat{\theta}_{t,e} can be obtained based on (17), given as

Î”â€‹Î¸^t,e=Gt,eâ€‹(X^,Y^)=âˆ’Î·â€‹âˆ‘b=1Bâˆ‡Î¸t,e,bâ„“â€‹(X^t,e,b,Y^t,e,b).Î”subscript^ğœƒğ‘¡ğ‘’subscriptğºğ‘¡ğ‘’^ğ‘‹^ğ‘Œğœ‚superscriptsubscriptğ‘1ğµsubscriptâˆ‡subscriptğœƒğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘â„“subscript^ğ‘‹ğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘subscript^ğ‘Œğ‘¡ğ‘’ğ‘\Delta\hat{\theta}_{t,e}=G_{t,e}(\hat{X},\hat{Y})=-\eta\sum_{b=1}^{B}\nabla_{\theta_{t,e,b}}\ell\left(\hat{X}_{t,e,b},\hat{Y}_{t,e,b}\right). (21)

Finally, the attack can be conducted following the procedures of Scenario 3.

4.2 Improved Weighted Loss Function for the Data Reconstruction Attack

The standard loss function (10) for the data reconstruction attack treats different components of the model update Î”â€‹Î¸tÎ”subscriptğœƒğ‘¡\Delta\theta_{t} equally. However, as observed in chen2019shallowing , different layers in a neural network provide different contributions to boosting the performance. Inspired by this fact, we propose to assign different weights to the model updates in different layers to facilitate the reconstruction. The implementation of our method is elaborated in this section.

Consider a neural network with Lğ¿L layers. Then the model update Î”â€‹Î¸tÎ”subscriptğœƒğ‘¡\Delta\theta_{t} consists of superposition of the updates Î”â€‹Î¸t(l)Î”superscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘¡ğ‘™\Delta\theta_{t}^{(l)} of each layer:

Î”â€‹Î¸t={Î”â€‹Î¸t(l)}l=1L.Î”subscriptğœƒğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptÎ”superscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘¡ğ‘™ğ‘™1ğ¿\Delta\theta_{t}=\{\Delta\theta_{t}^{(l)}\}_{l=1}^{L}. (22)

The same applies to the dummy model updates Î”â€‹Î¸t^={Î”â€‹Î¸^t(l)}l=1LÎ”^subscriptğœƒğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptÎ”superscriptsubscript^ğœƒğ‘¡ğ‘™ğ‘™1ğ¿\Delta\hat{\theta_{t}}=\{\Delta\hat{\theta}_{t}^{(l)}\}_{l=1}^{L}.

By assigning the weight q(l)>0superscriptğ‘ğ‘™0q^{(l)}>0 to the model updates at layer lğ‘™l, the loss function (10) for the attack becomes

â„“Qâ€‹(X^,Y^)=âˆ‘l=1Lq(l)â€‹â€–Î”â€‹Î¸^t(l)âˆ’Î”â€‹Î¸t(l)â€–2.subscriptâ„“ğ‘„^ğ‘‹^ğ‘Œsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘™1ğ¿superscriptğ‘ğ‘™superscriptnormÎ”superscriptsubscript^ğœƒğ‘¡ğ‘™Î”superscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘¡ğ‘™2\ell_{Q}(\hat{X},\hat{Y})=\sum_{l=1}^{L}q^{(l)}\left\|\Delta\hat{\theta}_{t}^{(l)}-\Delta\theta_{t}^{(l)}\right\|^{2}. (23)

Then, the crucial question is how to choose layer weights q(l)superscriptğ‘ğ‘™q^{(l)} to improve the reconstruction.

4.2.1 Design of Layer Weights

Increasing weights layer by layer.

We consider linearly increasing weight functions for difference types of layers.

To expose our ideas clearly, we focus on the commonly used ResNet architecture he2016deep , which contains convolutional, batch normalization, and fully connected layers.

We design the following weight functions for each kind of layer:

qcâ€‹v(l)={qcâ€‹vâˆ’1Lcâ€‹vâˆ’1â€‹(lâˆ’1)+1,ifÂ â€‹l=1,2,â€¦,Lcâ€‹v>1,qcâ€‹v,ifÂ â€‹l=Lcâ€‹v=1,superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘ğ‘£ğ‘™casessubscriptğ‘ğ‘ğ‘£1subscriptğ¿ğ‘ğ‘£1ğ‘™11formulae-sequenceifÂ ğ‘™12â€¦subscriptğ¿ğ‘ğ‘£1subscriptğ‘ğ‘ğ‘£ifÂ ğ‘™subscriptğ¿ğ‘ğ‘£1\displaystyle\begin{split}q_{cv}^{(l)}&=\begin{cases}\frac{q_{cv}-1}{L_{cv}-1}(l-1)+1,&\text{if }l=1,2,...,L_{cv}>1,\\ q_{cv},&\text{if }l=L_{cv}=1,\end{cases}\end{split} (24a)
qbâ€‹n(l)={qbâ€‹nâˆ’1Lbâ€‹nâˆ’1â€‹(lâˆ’1)+1,ifÂ â€‹l=1,2,â€¦,Lbâ€‹n>1,qbâ€‹n,ifÂ â€‹l=Lbâ€‹n=1,superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘™casessubscriptğ‘ğ‘ğ‘›1subscriptğ¿ğ‘ğ‘›1ğ‘™11formulae-sequenceifÂ ğ‘™12â€¦subscriptğ¿ğ‘ğ‘›1subscriptğ‘ğ‘ğ‘›ifÂ ğ‘™subscriptğ¿ğ‘ğ‘›1\displaystyle\begin{split}q_{bn}^{(l)}&=\begin{cases}\frac{q_{bn}-1}{L_{bn}-1}(l-1)+1,&\text{if }l=1,2,...,L_{bn}>1,\\ q_{bn},&\text{if }l=L_{bn}=1,\end{cases}\end{split} (24b)
qfâ€‹c(l)={qfâ€‹câˆ’1Lfâ€‹câˆ’1â€‹(lâˆ’1)+1,ifÂ â€‹l=1,2,â€¦,Lfâ€‹c>1,qfâ€‹c,ifÂ â€‹l=Lfâ€‹c=1,superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘“ğ‘ğ‘™casessubscriptğ‘ğ‘“ğ‘1subscriptğ¿ğ‘“ğ‘1ğ‘™11formulae-sequenceifÂ ğ‘™12â€¦subscriptğ¿ğ‘“ğ‘1subscriptğ‘ğ‘“ğ‘ifÂ ğ‘™subscriptğ¿ğ‘“ğ‘1\displaystyle\begin{split}q_{fc}^{(l)}&=\begin{cases}\frac{q_{fc}-1}{L_{fc}-1}(l-1)+1,&\text{if }l=1,2,...,L_{fc}>1,\\ q_{fc},&\text{if }l=L_{fc}=1,\end{cases}\end{split} (24c)

where Lcâ€‹vsubscriptğ¿ğ‘ğ‘£L_{cv}, Lbâ€‹nsubscriptğ¿ğ‘ğ‘›L_{bn}, and Lfâ€‹csubscriptğ¿ğ‘“ğ‘L_{fc} are the numbers of the convolutional, batch normalization, and fully connected layers, respectively, and L=Lcâ€‹v+Lbâ€‹n+Lfâ€‹cğ¿subscriptğ¿ğ‘ğ‘£subscriptğ¿ğ‘ğ‘›subscriptğ¿ğ‘“ğ‘L=L_{cv}+L_{bn}+L_{fc}. The values of qcâ€‹v>1subscriptğ‘ğ‘ğ‘£1q_{cv}>1, qbâ€‹n>1subscriptğ‘ğ‘ğ‘›1q_{bn}>1 and qfâ€‹c>1subscriptğ‘ğ‘“ğ‘1q_{fc}>1 are the largest weights assigned to the last layer. For a given neural network with a fixed number of layers (Lcâ€‹vsubscriptğ¿ğ‘ğ‘£L_{cv}, Lbâ€‹nsubscriptğ¿ğ‘ğ‘›L_{bn} and Lfâ€‹csubscriptğ¿ğ‘“ğ‘L_{fc}), the values of qcâ€‹vsubscriptğ‘ğ‘ğ‘£q_{cv}, qbâ€‹nsubscriptğ‘ğ‘ğ‘›q_{bn} and qfâ€‹csubscriptğ‘ğ‘“ğ‘q_{fc} determine the slope of the linearly increasing weight functions in (24).

Enhancing the weights of layers with larger errors.

Adding linearly increasing weights determined by (24) to the loss function (23) may overly emphasize the importance of some layers in the neural network and lead to a biased reconstruction. To strike a balance between adding linearly increasing weights and avoiding biased reconstructions, we propose to modify the weights of layers with larger errors by exploiting the statistical information like the mean Î¼â€‹(â‹…)ğœ‡â‹…\mu(\cdot) and the variance Ïƒ2â€‹(â‹…)superscriptğœ2â‹…\sigma^{2}(\cdot) of the layer-wise model updates {Î”â€‹Î¸t(l)}l=1LsuperscriptsubscriptÎ”superscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘¡ğ‘™ğ‘™1ğ¿\{\Delta\theta_{t}^{(l)}\}_{l=1}^{L} in (22). The procedure of our enhancing method is elaborated below.

4.2.2 Choice of Qğ‘„Q by Bayesian Optimization

Objective function.

As shown in (32), one can obtain the reconstructed data (X^âˆ—,Y^âˆ—)superscript^ğ‘‹superscript^ğ‘Œ(\hat{X}^{*},\hat{Y}^{*}) with a given Qğ‘„Q. Then, the corresponding dummy model update Î”â€‹Î¸^âˆ—Î”superscript^ğœƒ\Delta\hat{\theta}^{*} can be calculated as Î”â€‹Î¸^âˆ—=Gtâ€‹(X^âˆ—,Y^âˆ—)Î”superscript^ğœƒsubscriptğºğ‘¡superscript^ğ‘‹superscript^ğ‘Œ\Delta\hat{\theta}^{*}=G_{t}(\hat{X}^{*},\hat{Y}^{*}).

Let f:â„6â†’â„:ğ‘“â†’superscriptâ„6â„f:\mathbb{R}^{6}\rightarrow\mathbb{R} be the objective function in the form of l2subscriptğ‘™2l_{2} distance of the dummy model update Î”â€‹Î¸^âˆ—Î”superscript^ğœƒ\Delta\hat{\theta}^{*} and the ground-truth model update Î”â€‹Î¸Î”ğœƒ\Delta\theta as follows:

fâ€‹(Q)=â€–Î”â€‹Î¸^tâˆ—âˆ’Î”â€‹Î¸tâ€–2.ğ‘“ğ‘„superscriptnormÎ”subscriptsuperscript^ğœƒğ‘¡Î”subscriptğœƒğ‘¡2f(Q)=\left\|\Delta\hat{\theta}^{*}_{t}-\Delta\theta_{t}\right\|^{2}. (33)

Finding the optimal Qâˆ—superscriptğ‘„Q^{*} is equivalent to solving the following optimization problem:

Qâˆ—=argâ¡minQâ¡fâ€‹(Q).superscriptğ‘„subscriptğ‘„ğ‘“ğ‘„Q^{*}=\arg\min_{Q}f(Q). (34)

For this optimization problem, fğ‘“f is a black box function that does not have an analytic expression. Meanwhile, calculating fğ‘“f is computationally expensive since one has to complete a reconstruction attack to obtain (X^âˆ—,Y^âˆ—)superscript^ğ‘‹superscript^ğ‘Œ(\hat{X}^{*},\hat{Y}^{*}). Hence, traditional parameter determination methods like grid search are not feasible. To overcome the above difficulties, we employ the Bayesian optimization frazier2018tutorial to solve (34).

A Bayesian optimization algorithm for (34).

Bayesian optimization is a powerful technique for optimizing black-box functions that are expensive to evaluate and may have noise or other sources of uncertainty frazier2018tutorial . In general, Bayesian optimization iteratively uses a surrogate function to approximate the black-box function and then employs an acquisition function to determine the next set of parameters to evaluate.

The surrogate model works to approximate the black-box objective function fğ‘“f, which is commonly chosen to be a Gaussian process (GP). Formally, a GP is a collection of random variables, any finite number of which have a joint Gaussian distribution rasmussen2006gaussian .

Given an initial set ğ’ª={(ğ‘¸,ğ’‡)}:={Qi,fâ€‹(Qi)}i=1nğ’ªğ‘¸ğ’‡assignsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ‘„ğ‘–ğ‘“subscriptğ‘„ğ‘–ğ‘–1ğ‘›\mathcal{O}=\{(\bm{Q},\bm{f})\}:=\left\{Q_{i},f(Q_{i})\right\}_{i=1}^{n} that contains nğ‘›n pairs of the sampling points and their function values, the resulting prior distribution over ğ’‡ğ’‡\bm{f} can be given as

ğ’‡âˆ¼ğ’©â€‹(ğ,ğšº),similar-toğ’‡ğ’©ğğšº\bm{f}\sim\mathcal{N}(\bm{\mu},\bm{\Sigma}), (35)

where ğ=(Î¼â€‹(Q1),â€¦,Î¼â€‹(Qn))ğğœ‡subscriptğ‘„1â€¦ğœ‡subscriptğ‘„ğ‘›\bm{\mu}=\left(\mu\left(Q_{1}\right),\ldots,\mu\left(Q_{n}\right)\right), Î¼ğœ‡\mu is the mean function and commonly set to zero, ğšº=Îºâ€‹(ğ‘¸,ğ‘¸)ğšºğœ…ğ‘¸ğ‘¸\bm{\Sigma}=\kappa\left(\bm{Q},\bm{Q}\right), and Îºğœ…\kappa is a positive definite kernel function usually set to be the Gaussian kernel.

Then, we can infer the value of fâ€‹(Q)ğ‘“ğ‘„f(Q) at any point Qğ‘„Q by computing the posterior distribution of fâ€‹(Q)ğ‘“ğ‘„f(Q) given prior observations using Bayesâ€™ rule rasmussen2006gaussian :

fâ€‹(Q)âˆ£ğ’‡conditionalğ‘“ğ‘„ğ’‡\displaystyle f(Q)\mid\bm{f} âˆ¼ğ’©â€‹(Î¼â€‹(Q),Ïƒ2â€‹(Q)),similar-toabsentğ’©ğœ‡ğ‘„superscriptğœ2ğ‘„\displaystyle\sim\mathcal{N}(\mu(Q),\sigma^{2}(Q)), (36)
Î¼â€‹(Q)ğœ‡ğ‘„\displaystyle\mu(Q) =Îºâ€‹(Q,ğ‘¸)â€‹ğšºâˆ’1â€‹ğ’‡,absentğœ…ğ‘„ğ‘¸superscriptğšº1ğ’‡\displaystyle=\kappa(Q,\bm{Q})\bm{\Sigma}^{-1}\bm{f},
Ïƒ2â€‹(Q)superscriptğœ2ğ‘„\displaystyle\sigma^{2}(Q) =Îºâ€‹(Q,Q)âˆ’Îºâ€‹(Q,ğ‘¸)â€‹ğšºâˆ’1â€‹Îºâ€‹(ğ‘¸,Q).absentğœ…ğ‘„ğ‘„ğœ…ğ‘„ğ‘¸superscriptğšº1ğœ…ğ‘¸ğ‘„\displaystyle=\kappa(Q,Q)-\kappa(Q,\bm{Q})\bm{\Sigma}^{-1}\kappa(\bm{Q},Q).

The role of the acquisition function is to propose the parameters for the next trial by trading off exploitation and exploration. Exploitation means sampling where the surrogate model predicts a high objective and exploration means sampling at locations where the prediction uncertainty is high.

One of the most popular acquisition functions is Expected Improvement (EI) mockus1975bayesian . Let fminsubscriptğ‘“f_{\min} denote the best function value obtained so far. Then, the improvement over fminsubscriptğ‘“f_{\min} at point Qğ‘„Q can be defined as

Iâ€‹(Q)=maxâ¡(fminâˆ’fâ€‹(Q),0).ğ¼ğ‘„subscriptğ‘“ğ‘“ğ‘„0I(Q)=\max(f_{\min}-f(Q),0). (37)

The improvement Iâ€‹(Q)ğ¼ğ‘„I(Q) is a random variable since fâ€‹(Q)âˆ¼ğ’©â€‹(Î¼â€‹(Q),Ïƒ2â€‹(Q))similar-toğ‘“ğ‘„ğ’©ğœ‡ğ‘„superscriptğœ2ğ‘„f(Q)\sim\mathcal{N}\left(\mu(Q),\sigma^{2}(Q)\right) as shown in (36). To obtain the expected improvement we can take the expected value as follows:

EIâ€‹(Q)=ğ”¼â€‹[maxâ¡(fminâˆ’fâ€‹(Q),0)].EIğ‘„ğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptğ‘“ğ‘“ğ‘„0\mathrm{EI}(Q)=\mathbb{E}[\max(f_{\min}-f(Q),0)]. (38)

The expected improvement can be evaluated analytically under the GP jones1998efficient , given as:

EIâ€‹(Q)=(fminâˆ’Î¼â€‹(Q))â€‹Î¦â€‹(fminâˆ’Î¼â€‹(Q)Ïƒâ€‹(Q))+Ïƒâ€‹(Q)â€‹Ï•â€‹(fminâˆ’Î¼â€‹(Q)Ïƒâ€‹(Q)),EIğ‘„subscriptğ‘“ğœ‡ğ‘„Î¦subscriptğ‘“ğœ‡ğ‘„ğœğ‘„ğœğ‘„italic-Ï•subscriptğ‘“ğœ‡ğ‘„ğœğ‘„\mathrm{EI}(Q)=\left(f_{\min}-\mu(Q)\right)\Phi\left(\frac{f_{\min}-\mu(Q)}{\sigma(Q)}\right)+\sigma(Q)\phi\left(\frac{f_{\min}-\mu(Q)}{\sigma(Q)}\right), (39)

where Ï•italic-Ï•\phi and Î¦Î¦\Phi are the probability density and cumulative distribution functions of the standard normal distribution, respectively. It can be seen that the value of the function EIEI\mathrm{EI} is high for a point Qğ‘„Q predicted to have a small Î¼â€‹(Q)ğœ‡ğ‘„\mu(Q) and a large Ïƒâ€‹(Q)ğœğ‘„\sigma(Q), indicating the trade-off between the exploitation and exploration.

Given the EIEI\mathrm{EI}, the parameter Qğ‘„Q for the next trial is chosen to be the point with the largest expected improvement:

Q=argâ¡maxQâ¡EIâ€‹(Q).ğ‘„subscriptğ‘„EIğ‘„Q=\arg\max_{Q}\mathrm{EI}(Q). (40)

The evaluation of EIâ€‹(Q)EIğ‘„\mathrm{EI}(Q) is much easier than that of the function fğ‘“f in (34). The optimization problem (40) can be solved by some classic optimization techniques such as Newtonâ€™s method.

4.3 Approximate and weighted data reconstruction attack method

Based on the discussions in Sections 4.1-4.2, we propose an approximate and weighted data reconstruction attack method and list it in AlgorithmÂ 2.

5 Experimental Tests

In this section, we report some numerical results to validate the effectiveness of our proposed AWA method given in AlgorithmÂ 2. We first introduce experimental environments and implementation details used in our experiments. We then explain the choice of hyperparameters and describe the evaluation metrics. After that, we test the AWA for image data reconstruction and compare the performance of AWA with two state-of-the-art attack algorithms (AGIC xu2022agic and DLG zhu2019deep ) in different FedAvg scenarios.

5.1 Setups

Hardware.

For all the experiments, we use a computer equipped with an Xeon E5-2680 v4 CPU, 32GB of RAM, and an NVIDIA GeForce RTX 1080 Ti GPU.

Implementation details.

To implement the FedAvg, some images from the dataset CIFAR-10 (size 32 Ã— 32, 10 classes) krizhevsky2009learning are used as the clientsâ€™ training data. The model used by each client is the ResNet18 he2016deep , which contains 17 convolutional layers, 17 batch-normalization layers, and 1 fully connected layer. The clientâ€™s local training uses a stochastic gradient descent with a learning rate of 0.001. For the attack optimizations in (11), the Adam optimizer kingma2017adam with a learning rate of 0.1 is used and each attack runs for 1000 iterations. Following the label inference method in geng2023improved ; yin2021see , we proceed with the assumption that the label information is known. TableÂ 1 lists the simulation scenarios of the data reconstruction attack.

In the AWA method, the parameter Qğ‘„Q (31) is selected by the Bayesian optimization frazier2018tutorial , where we use the Gaussian process (36) as the surrogate model and the expected improvement (39) as the acquisition function. The objective function of the Bayesian optimization is the squared Euclidean distance of the dummy model update Î”â€‹Î¸^âˆ—Î”superscript^ğœƒ\Delta\hat{\theta}^{*} and the ground-truth model update Î”â€‹Î¸Î”ğœƒ\Delta\theta as defined in (33). We run the Bayesian optimization for NBâ€‹O=50subscriptğ‘ğµğ‘‚50N_{BO}=50 iterations, with the first n=12ğ‘›12n=12 iterations initiating the dataset ğ’ªğ’ª\mathcal{O}. The search ranges of Qğ‘„Q are listed in TableÂ 2.

Evaluation metrics.

In order to evaluate the efficiency of the attach and the quality of the data reconstruction, we use three different metrics to measure the dissimilarity between reconstructed data and the real data: pixel-wise Mean Square Error (MSE), Peak Signal-to-Noise Ratio (PSNR) sara2019image , and Structural Similarity Index Measure (SSIM) wang2004imagea . The above three metrics are prevalent and appropriate indicators in evaluating the effect of image reconstruction sara2019image , and they have been widely used in evaluating the existing data reconstruction attacks, see geiping2020inverting ; wei2020framework ; yin2021see .

  • â€¢

    MSE is the degree of variation between the original image ğ‘«ğ‘«\bm{D} and the reconstruction image ğ‘«â€²superscriptğ‘«bold-â€²\bm{D^{\prime}} and is defined by

    MSEâ¡(ğ‘«,ğ‘«â€²)=1dmâ€‹dnâ€‹âˆ‘i=0dmâˆ’1âˆ‘j=0dnâˆ’1[ğ‘«â€‹(i,j)âˆ’ğ‘«â€²â€‹(i,j)]2,MSEğ‘«superscriptğ‘«bold-â€²1subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘–0subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘š1superscriptsubscriptğ‘—0subscriptğ‘‘ğ‘›1superscriptdelimited-[]ğ‘«ğ‘–ğ‘—superscriptğ‘«bold-â€²ğ‘–ğ‘—2\operatorname{MSE}(\bm{D},\bm{D^{\prime}})=\frac{1}{d_{m}d_{n}}\sum_{i=0}^{d_{m}-1}\sum_{j=0}^{d_{n}-1}[\bm{D}(i,j)-\bm{D^{\prime}}(i,j)]^{2},

    where dmÃ—dnsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘›d_{m}\times d_{n} is the dimension of images; ğ‘«â€‹(i,j)ğ‘«ğ‘–ğ‘—\bm{D}(i,j) and ğ‘«â€²â€‹(i,j)superscriptğ‘«bold-â€²ğ‘–ğ‘—\bm{D^{\prime}}(i,j) are the pixel values at coordinates (i,j)ğ‘–ğ‘—(i,j) of ğ‘«ğ‘«\bm{D} and ğ‘«â€²superscriptğ‘«bold-â€²\bm{D^{\prime}}. Clearly, a smaller value of MSE indicates a better reconstruction quality.

  • â€¢

    PSNR represents the rate of the maximum possible signal power to the distortion noise power. PSNR is calculated as

    PSNRâ¡(ğ‘«,ğ‘«â€²)=10â€‹log10â¡Maxğ‘«2MSEâ¡(ğ‘«,ğ‘«â€²),PSNRğ‘«superscriptğ‘«bold-â€²10subscript10superscriptsubscriptMaxğ‘«2MSEğ‘«superscriptğ‘«bold-â€²\operatorname{PSNR}(\bm{D},\bm{D^{\prime}})=10\log_{10}\frac{\operatorname{Max}_{\bm{D}}^{2}}{\operatorname{MSE}(\bm{D},\bm{D^{\prime}})},

    where Maxğ‘«subscriptMaxğ‘«\operatorname{Max}_{\bm{D}} is the maximum possible value of pixels in the original image ğ‘«ğ‘«\bm{D}. It is easy to see that the larger the PSNR value, the better the image reconstruction quality.

  • â€¢

    SSIM measures the structural similarity between the original and reconstructed images. The value of SSIM ranges between zero and one, with a higher value indicating a better reconstruction. To be concrete, SSIM is calculated as

    SSIMâ¡(ğ‘«,ğ‘«â€²)=(2â€‹Î¼ğ‘«â€‹Î¼ğ‘«â€²+c1)â€‹(2â€‹Ïƒğ‘«â€‹ğ‘«â€²+c2)(Î¼ğ‘«2+Î¼ğ‘«â€²2+c1)â€‹(Ïƒğ‘«2+Ïƒğ‘«â€²2+c2).SSIMğ‘«superscriptğ‘«bold-â€²2subscriptğœ‡ğ‘«subscriptğœ‡superscriptğ‘«bold-â€²subscriptğ‘12subscriptğœğ‘«superscriptğ‘«bold-â€²subscriptğ‘2superscriptsubscriptğœ‡ğ‘«2superscriptsubscriptğœ‡superscriptğ‘«bold-â€²2subscriptğ‘1superscriptsubscriptğœğ‘«2superscriptsubscriptğœsuperscriptğ‘«bold-â€²2subscriptğ‘2\operatorname{SSIM}(\bm{D},\bm{D^{\prime}})=\frac{\left(2\mu_{\bm{D}}\mu_{\bm{D^{\prime}}}+c_{1}\right)\left(2\sigma_{\bm{D}\bm{D^{\prime}}}+c_{2}\right)}{\left(\mu_{\bm{D}}^{2}+\mu_{\bm{D^{\prime}}}^{2}+c_{1}\right)\left(\sigma_{\bm{D}}^{2}+\sigma_{\bm{D^{\prime}}}^{2}+c_{2}\right)}.

    Here, Î¼ğ‘«subscriptğœ‡ğ‘«\mu_{\bm{D}} and Î¼ğ‘«â€²subscriptğœ‡superscriptğ‘«bold-â€²\mu_{\bm{D^{\prime}}} are the average pixel values of ğ‘«ğ‘«\bm{D} and ğ‘«â€²superscriptğ‘«bold-â€²\bm{D^{\prime}}, Ïƒğ‘«subscriptğœğ‘«\sigma_{\bm{D}} and Ïƒğ‘«â€²subscriptğœsuperscriptğ‘«bold-â€²\sigma_{\bm{D^{\prime}}} are the standard deviations of pixel values of ğ‘«ğ‘«\bm{D} and ğ‘«â€²superscriptğ‘«bold-â€²\bm{D^{\prime}}, Ïƒğ‘«â€‹ğ‘«â€²subscriptğœğ‘«superscriptğ‘«bold-â€²\sigma_{\bm{D}\bm{D^{\prime}}} is the covariance of ğ‘«ğ‘«\bm{D} and ğ‘«â€²superscriptğ‘«bold-â€²\bm{D^{\prime}}, c1=(k1â€‹H)2subscriptğ‘1superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ»2c_{1}=\left(k_{1}H\right)^{2} and c2=(k2â€‹H)2subscriptğ‘2superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜2ğ»2c_{2}=\left(k_{2}H\right)^{2} are constants with k1=0.01subscriptğ‘˜10.01k_{1}=0.01, k2=0.03subscriptğ‘˜20.03k_{2}=0.03, and Hğ»H being the dynamic range of the pixel-values.

5.2 Results for Image Data Reconstruction Attacks

To verify the feasibility and effectiveness of the proposed AWA method, we test it in image data reconstruction attacks and compared it with two state-of-the-art attack methods (AGIC xu2022agic and DLG zhu2019deep ) under the following four different FedAvg scenarios:

  • â€¢

    Case 1: N=4ğ‘4N=4, E=1ğ¸1E=1, and B=1ğµ1B=1,

  • â€¢

    Case 2: N=4ğ‘4N=4, E=4ğ¸4E=4, and B=1ğµ1B=1,

  • â€¢

    Case 3: N=4ğ‘4N=4, E=1ğ¸1E=1, and B=4ğµ4B=4,

  • â€¢

    Case 4: N=4ğ‘4N=4, E=2ğ¸2E=2, and B=2ğµ2B=2.

Recall the analysis in SectionÂ 3, when E>1ğ¸1E>1 and B>1ğµ1B>1, the attacker has to use an approximate method for the attack. Therefore, only AWA and AGIC can conduct the attack for Case 4. The approximate strategy of each method is given below. Our proposed AWA method uses (20) to get the approximate intermediate model updates Î”â€‹Î¸~t,eÎ”subscript~ğœƒğ‘¡ğ‘’\Delta\tilde{\theta}_{t,e} in each epoch e=1,2,â€¦,Eğ‘’12â€¦ğ¸e=1,2,\ldots,E. Then, the attacker can reconstruct the clientâ€™s dataset by using any of the Î”â€‹Î¸~t,eÎ”subscript~ğœƒğ‘¡ğ‘’\Delta\tilde{\theta}_{t,e} and the corresponding Gt,esubscriptğºğ‘¡ğ‘’G_{t,e}. In Case 4 with E=2ğ¸2E=2, we have two optional approximate intermediate model updates: Î”â€‹Î¸~t,1Î”subscript~ğœƒğ‘¡1\Delta\tilde{\theta}_{t,1} and Î”â€‹Î¸~t,2Î”subscript~ğœƒğ‘¡2\Delta\tilde{\theta}_{t,2}. In the test, we choose Î”â€‹Î¸~t,1Î”subscript~ğœƒğ‘¡1\Delta\tilde{\theta}_{t,1} as the target model update for the reconstruction. On the other hand, AGIC assumes that a combined batch consisting of all the mini-batches used in the clientâ€™s local training process can approximate the received model update in a single local update step. For this purpose, it initializes the dummy data with the same size as the combined mini-batches (NÃ—Eğ‘ğ¸N\times E) and calculates the dummy model update by performing one local update step using the combined dummy data.

In all the tests, the DLG method utilizes the unweighted loss function (10) for the attack, while the AGIC method employs a weighted cosine similarity loss function by assigning linearly increasing weights to convolutional and fully connected layers. However, these weights are assigned empirically and not tailored case by case. In contrast, the AWA method employs the weighted and enhanced loss function (23) for the attack, with the layer weights determined by (24) and (27). The values of parameter Qğ‘„Q are selected by utilizing the Bayesian optimization frazier2018tutorial . The cumulative minimum loss fâ€‹(Q)ğ‘“ğ‘„f(Q) of the Bayesian optimization in 50 trials are presented in FigureÂ 1. It can be seen that the Bayesian optimization approach successfully finds a trend of smaller fâ€‹(Q)ğ‘“ğ‘„f(Q) values as the trial count increases. Then, the parameter settings in our AWA method for each case are listed in TableÂ 3.

The numerical comparisons of the above three data reconstruction attack methods for Cases 1-4 are presented in FigureÂ 2 and TableÂ 4. We observe that in all four cases, our proposed AWA method consistently yields images with substantially enhanced resolution compared to those obtained by DLG and AGIC. This is further validated by the consistently highest values of PSNR and SSIM achieved by AWA in each case. Another noteworthy finding is the consistency in the reconstruction qualities of images produced by our AWA method across the diverse FedAvg cases, which demonstrates the robustness of our proposed approach.

In Case 4, where E>1ğ¸1E>1 and B>1ğµ1B>1, DLG encounters difficulties in performing the attack due to the absence of an approximate strategy. On the other hand, although AGIC incorporates an approximate strategy, it fails to reconstruct images with identifiable objects effectively. In sharp contrast, the proposed AWA method demonstrates its capability to successfully reconstruct images with reasonable resolutions, overcoming the limitations faced by DLG and AGIC. Furthermore, the PSNR of images reconstructed in Case 4 is found to be comparable to that achieved in the first three cases, which strongly suggests the effectiveness of our proposed approximate strategy.

Furthermore, we implement the AWA method with 3000 iterations for four cases. All the other parameters maintain consistency with the original experiment setup. The resulting reconstructed images and the corresponding SSIM metrics for each case are represented in FigureÂ 3. Evidently, the attained SSIM values surpass those presented in TableÂ 4 for the 1000-iteration attack. The results clearly show a significant visual proximity between the reconstructed images and their original counterparts. Additionally, FigureÂ 4 presents the evaluation metrics PSNR and SSIM, as well as the cumulative minimum value of the weighted loss during the attack across the four cases. It is evident that our method achieves a satisfactory level of reconstruction, with SSIM values exceeding 0.9 within 1500 attack iterations for all four cases. The outcomes of Case 4 exhibit a marginally inferior performance compared to Cases 1-3 due to the need of approximation. However, the reconstructed images in Case 4 remain sufficiently lucid to facilitate object identification. These results further validate the efficiency and effectiveness of our proposed AWA method.

Overall, the above results show the significant enhancement in reconstruction performance achieved by our proposed AWA method. The comprehensive evaluation provides strong evidence supporting the superiority of our method AWA in data reconstruction attacks for the considered FedAvg scenarios.

6 Conclusions

Although Federated Learning (FL) has emerged as a contemporary paradigm for safe distributed learning, its potential privacy benefits are compromised by data reconstruction attacks. In this paper, we first formulate the attack as an inverse problem (8), allowing us to reconstruct the clientâ€™s training data iteratively by solving an optimization problem (11). To attack the widely used FedAvg scenario, we propose an interpolation-based approximation method (20), where the intermediate model updates corresponding to each epoch are approximated by interpolating the model parameters. Furthermore, we propose a layer-wise weighted and enhanced loss function (23) for the attack to improve the quality of reconstructed data. By assigning appropriate weights to model updates in different layers solving (34), using the Bayesian optimization method, we achieve superior reconstruction results compared to the existing state-of-the-art methods. Moreover, our method is compatible with various neural network architectures like Convolutional Neural Networks and Residual Neural Networks. Numerical results validate that our proposed approximate and weighted data reconstruction attack method is effective for adversaries to exploit the vulnerabilities of FL systems utilizing Federated Averaging algorithms. The ability to reconstruct data from intermediate model updates highlights the need for robust defense mechanisms. Future research could focus on developing countermeasures and enhancing the security of FL frameworks to mitigate the risks associated with such attacks.
